conversation.content: You're the UN representative? Didn't expect to see you at the range today.

Oh, yeah, I'm actually here for the, um, peacekeeping training certification scores. Let me start with the first set—seventeen, twenty-three, nine. It's mandatory for field assignments now, which is honestly kind of surreal.
Wait, you're reading scores while we're actively shooting?

Uh-huh, I know it seems weird but apparently this is how they want it done. Next sequence—thirty-one, twelve, forty-five. The idea is that we practice maintaining focus under, you know, actual firing conditions.
That's insane. How do you concentrate?

[chuckle] Well, I mean, after three years of budget meetings in conflict zones, a little gunfire is almost relaxing. Seven, nineteen, twenty-eight. Though I'll admit my ears are definitely not happy about this arrangement.
Which delegation are you with again?

The humanitarian affairs division, which makes this whole thing even more, erm, ironic really. Fifty-two, eleven, thirty-six. We're supposed to be the ones pushing for non-violent solutions but here I am reading target scores.
[deep pitch] Your accent—is that Scottish?

[anxious] Yeah, Edinburgh originally, though I've been bouncing between New York and Geneva for so long that it's kind of, uhh, faded a bit. Twenty-one, forty, fifteen. Sometimes I forget which words I pronounce which way anymore.
[pause] Sorry, just reloading. Keep going with the numbers.

No worries, take your time. Next set—sixty-three, eight, twenty-nine. You know, it's actually fascinating how different countries approach these certification tests, like the Swiss require twice as many rounds as we do.
Really? That seems excessive.

[loudly] Oh absolutely, but they're sticklers for precision! Eighteen, thirty-four, four! Their whole philosophy is that if you're going to carry a weapon in peacekeeping operations, you better be, um, exceptionally qualified!
[frustrated] Damn, missed that last target completely.

[sneeze] Ah, excuse me—the cordite always gets me. Don't worry about it though, everyone misses sometimes. Twenty-six, fourteen, forty-one. I failed this test three times before I finally passed, if that makes you feel any better.
Three times? But you seem so calm about it now.

Well, I mean, repetition helps with everything eventually, right? Thirty-seven, ten, fifty-five. Plus my field partner kept reminding me that, uh, the numbers don't actually matter as much as staying composed while reading them.
Wait, so this is more about multitasking than accuracy?

[pause] Exactly, yeah. The whole exercise is basically stress inoculation—can you maintain diplomatic composure while, you know, chaos is happening around you. Last numbers for this round—twenty-two, forty-eight, sixteen.
